history.content:
Here's what the course staff for Fall 2018 shared with students on the same topic.

I was reading Richard Feynman's Lectures on Computation and I thought the first chapter, Introduction to Computation, was very relevant to the first few weeks' material. The entire chapter is publicly available as a preview on Google Books. It's a fun and informative read with a friendly narrative style, and will help with orienting yourself for the first few weeks of the course. Brian Harvey's (Teaching Professor Emeritus) Introduction to C is also a fantastic resource for getting acquainted with C.

For a deeper dive, pick up the textbook we'll be using for the first part of the course, Computer Organization and Design (RISC-V Edition).

Also, get "Human Resource Machine" -- addictive programming game that will teach you assembly programming thinking in a fun way.

children.subject: +1 to Human Resource Machine--it's really great :)

history.content: Considering the time left in break, what is the best way to prepare for 61c? Would it be be more helpful to try and take an online course in the C programming language, or try to go through the lecture videos and the corresponding discussions?
history.subject: preparation for 61c
